title: Amos' Visions and Confrontation
shortSummary: Amos 7 records three visions given to the prophet Amos, each demonstrating God's judgment on Israel and His mercy in response to Amos' intercession. The chapter culminates in a confrontation between Amos and Amaziah, the priest of Bethel, highlighting the cost of faithful prophecy and the divine call to proclaim God's word despite opposition.
timeline: c. 760-750 BC - Ministry of Amos during the reign of Jeroboam II in the Northern Kingdom of Israel

keyCharacters.name: Amos
keyCharacters.description: A shepherd and fruit gatherer called by God to prophesy against Israel's sin and warn of impending judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Amaziah
keyCharacters.description: The priest of Bethel who opposes Amos, accusing him of conspiracy and urging him to leave Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Jeroboam II
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel during Amos' ministry, whose reign is marked by prosperity but also idolatry and injustice.

definitions.definition: Symbolic of a devastating plague or judgment sent by God to consume the land's crops, representing destruction.

outline.heading: Three Visions of Judgment and Mercy
outline.description: Amos receives visions of a locust plague, fire consuming the deep, and God standing with a plumbline. Each vision depicts impending judgment on Israel, but God relents after Amos intercedes, showing both divine justice and mercy.

outline.heading: The Plumbline and God's Judgment on Israel
outline.description: God reveals Himself standing with a plumbline, symbolizing His measurement of Israel's sin. The high places and sanctuaries will be destroyed, and judgment will come upon Jeroboam's house, emphasizing inevitable divine discipline.

outline.heading: Confrontation with Amaziah the Priest
outline.description: Amaziah accuses Amos of conspiracy and commands him to leave Bethel. Amos defends his divine calling and prophesies judgment on Amaziah's family and Israel, underscoring the cost of obedience to God's word.

application: Trust in God's justice and mercy, recognizing that He disciplines His people but also responds to prayerful intercession.
Stand firm in obedience to God's calling even when facing opposition or rejection from religious authorities.
Recognize the seriousness of sin and idolatry, allowing God's standards to guide personal and communal holiness.
Pray earnestly for God's mercy on others, interceding on behalf of those who are distant from Him.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto me, Amos, what seest thou? And I said, A plumbline. Then said the Lord, Behold, I will set a plumbline in the midst of my people Israel: I will not again pass by them any more:
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's firm judgment against Israel, emphasizing that He will no longer overlook their sin.

keyVerses.text: Then answered Amos, and said to Amaziah, I was no prophet, neither was I a prophet's son; but I was an herdman, and a gatherer of sycomore fruit:
keyVerses.significance: Amos' humble origins highlight that God's call to ministry transcends social status and human qualifications.

keyVerses.text: Therefore thus saith the LORD; Thy wife shall be an harlot in the city, and thy sons and thy daughters shall fall by the sword, and thy land shall be divided by line; and thou shalt die in a polluted land: and Israel shall surely go into captivity forth of his land.
keyVerses.significance: This solemn prophecy underscores the severe consequences of opposing God's messenger and the coming judgment on Israel.
